messages.text: And Google is always getting harassed by Wall Street investors, yay or nay. And then the next time, they report earnings again. It's still almost all their money is from search and so dentists are doing fillings, crowns and root canals and that's not working. So they think they're going to go into sleep apnea or Invisalign or some other you know, they're going to do it on TMJ. And as I was like, "Dude, last year not even one percent of your revenue was TMJ and now you're on a six-week course."  And then I look at the .. Okay, last year, not even a half percent was from ortho and now you're going to some Invisalign course. Focus on search. You're a dentist, you have cleanings, you have a hygiene , you have fillings and crowns and stuff. If you can't crush it on your core competency like Google crushes on search, and I personally think Google throws away way too much money on all these superfluous ideas, which are really cool and sexy but at the end of the day, they cost half billion dollars, which all could have been profit given to their stockholders.   So stick to your core business. I want to get specifics. This is Dentistry Uncensored. I know my homies, they only want more new patients. They don't want any of the details. They're only calling you because they're dentists. They want to do more fillings and crowns in . So they're going to call you up and say, I want more new patients. Can you really look at them and say, "I can deliver you 10 more a month, 20 more a month?" I mean so for people listening to you, if they went to your website right now, .    Can they just call you up and say, "Hey, dude. I need it. You know, I'm paying all my bills. Everything's great but if I have had 10 more patients a month." or let's say they're not paying their bills. They say, "I need 20 new patients a month. Ca you deliver that?"

I think it depends on a lot of stuff. So when we get on a sales call with somebody perspective or once worked with us perspective client, we ask a lot of questions and I think that's probably something that doesn't happen with a lot of our competitors. We ask hard questions. We say, "What have you done in the past? What did that look like? How did it bring you new patients? What was your experience? How many patients are you getting now? How many patients did you get last year? How big is your office? What services do you offer? What insurance do you take? Do you take Medicare? Do you take Medicaid?

messages.text: I guess I don't ... What I do is not necessarily teaching sales, sales, sales. Instead teaching value, value, value. What is it that you want to do? What is the value of that? Do they understand the value of that? Do they know why it is worth it for a patient to do this? And then let's bring everyone along. Sometimes when I go in to work with dentists, they don't necessarily see the value of their dentistry. So that's one of the first thing I want to look at. I want to look at their treatment planning process even though I'm not a dentist. I want to see what is their thought process? Usually they just focus on one tooth or their staff member has already told them their insurance will pay for this and that's it. And so they focus on what kind of dentistry I can sell, if they even use that word, just within that insurance limitation. I rarely find a dentist who cannot communicate. If they can't communicate then I do want to hide them or not let them ruin it because sometimes they'll talk too soon. Talk too fast. Simple things like for example I time the consultation on doctors. How long does it take for a patient to accept treatment? How long? Is it five minutes, ten minutes? Is it 15 minutes or 45? I don't tell doctors talk five minutes and shut up. I just want to know when are you effective? When does a patient say yes in the conversation? When does the light bulb go on and they say oh I see this is what I want. When does that happen? Many times their staff members know and their staff members know when the doctor should shut up. Know what the doctor says that they shouldn't. I was in Nacogdoches, Texas, implant practice and the doctor wanted to do more implant dentistry. His staff told me, "You know he'll talk and talk and talk to a patient going from treatment plan to treatment plan to treatment plan to treatment plan until they accept a swing lock partial. I'll never forget that visit. I didn't even know what a swing lock partial was. I said what do you mean? What's a swing lock partial? They showed me. Little posterior segments that clicked in, locked in. At any rate, I said what do you mean he talks and talks until they accept a swing lock partial? And they said, "It's the last thing he's got to offer." He just presents this. If that doesn't hit he presents the next thing. If that doesn't hit he presents the next thing until the treatment value goes down and down and down and down and down until he has nothing of less value than the swing lock partial. I said so what should he do? They said, "If he would just shut up patients would accept treatment." I said well how can we get him to shut up? One doctor I timed, if he talked more than 15 minutes we audited simply the function of time. If he talked more

messages.content: Can you tell me about Joy Millis' approach to teaching implant dentistry? I'm interested in learning about her focus on value, value, value, and her strategies for effective communication with patients.

Hey, Mikhail! I'd be happy to discuss Joy Millis' approach to teaching implant dentistry.

Joy Millis focuses on teaching value, value, value, rather than emphasizing sales. She encourages dentists to consider the value of their dentistry and communicate that value to their patients.

When working with dentists, Millis examines their treatment planning process. She looks at the dentist's thought process and often finds that they focus on one tooth or limit their treatment plans based on insurance coverage.

Millis teaches dentists to communicate effectively by understanding the patient's perspective and knowing when to present different treatment options. She times consultations to determine the most effective duration for a patient to accept treatment.

In some cases, Millis has found that dentists talk too much or too fast, which can hinder the patient's understanding. To address this, she has implemented strategies such as auditing the function of time to ensure that the dentist is communicating effectively without overwhelming the patient.

By focusing on the value of their dentistry and improving communication with patients, Joy Millis helps dentists to increase their success in implant dentistry.

[Tag: The Business of Implant Dentistry]

Differentiate your practice from competitors by highlighting your unique skills, expertise, and services. This can help you attract patients who are looking for a specific treatment or experience.

messages.content: How can I effectively market my dental practice to attract more patients? I’ve been struggling with getting new patients in the door.

Hi Mikhail, let's dive into dental marketing.

# Effective Marketing Strategies

When it comes to marketing, remember that having a professional and engaging online presence is crucial. Make sure your website is visually appealing, easy to navigate, and clearly communicates your unique message and value proposition.

When you get emails from potential patients, ensure your email address is professional and easy to remember. It's also a good idea to include a photo of yourself and your team on your website to help establish a personal connection with your audience.

According to Dr. Leon Klempner, CEO of People & Practice, the average website is not doing a good job of representing the practice. Orthodontists are stepping up, but many websites are still missing the relationship of the website to the practice's message.

To stand out from the competition, focus on your unique selling points and communicate them effectively on your website and through other marketing channels.

## Relationship Building

Building relationships with your patients is essential for long-term success. By focusing on providing exceptional customer service and creating a welcoming environment, you can create a loyal patient base that will help your practice grow.

## Differentiating Your Practice

Differentiate your practice from competitors by highlighting your unique skills, expertise, and services. This can help you attract patients who are looking for a specific treatment or experience.

## Staying Ahead of the Competition

Keep an eye on the competition and stay updated on the latest trends and best practices in dental marketing. Practices that don't pay attention to their image and patient experience will lose to DSOs.

## Final Thoughts

To summarize, an effective marketing strategy for your dental practice should include a professional website, strong email communication, relationship building, differentiation, and staying ahead of the competition.

If you have any other questions, I’m here to help.

[Tag: Successful Dental Marketing]

messages.content: Can you tell me about the quality of dental implants and what to look for when choosing a manufacturer?

Hey, Mikhail. I'd be happy to discuss this topic with you.

# Dental Implant Quality

Dental implants can have impurities, with up to 25% to 30% of them showing minor and major particles. Dr. Dirk U. Duddeck, DDS at MegaGen, Las Vegas, mentioned that they use a special technique to detect these particles using a scanner electron microscope.

When looking for a manufacturer, it's important to consider the quality management. Bigger companies usually have a more controlled production process, while midsize companies might have more issues. There are approximately 1,000 manufacturers worldwide, and the number of implants with a controlled production process might be around 400.

Dr. Duddeck mentioned that MegaGen is one of the finest manufacturers he has seen under the microscope. Keep in mind that the quality of implants can vary significantly between manufacturers, and it's essential to choose a reputable one.

Do you have any specific concerns or questions about dental implants or manufacturers, Mikhail?

[Tag: Implant Quality and more]

chat.topic: Productive Dentist Academy with Dr. Bruce Baird : Howard Speaks Podcast #7

messages.text: Kim is a, I call him a dentist, but he is also an inventor and he thinks outside of the box.  And what he did was come up with basically a base rinse.  And this base rinse neutralizes acid in the mouth and it is the first time anybody has come out with anything like that.  And for me it is the first time in 34 years, and I have been using his product since he came out with it, that I feel like we have something that can literally stop decay.  If you have a basic environment in the mouth or a more neutral environment, you can’t get active decay.  And so I explain this to patients.  So my education is educating them about what they have to do, not what I am going to do for them.  And that is a big difference.  And so we hold them accountable every time they come in and this, you know, with Kim’s products he has the toothpaste, he has all of the stuff.  So it is something that we use ongoing.  Another fine example is when we look at their functional risk.  You know, we give them an occlusal guard.  You ask them at hygiene visits, "So, how is the occlusal guard working?"  And they go, "Uhhh, pretty good."  You know, or you say, "Hey, are you wearing it?"  "Well, yeah sometimes," which that means they are never wearing it.  They don’t even know where it is.  Their dog ate it two months ago.  So we look at them and we say, "You know, you have got to wear this every night.  We know that we have done this work.  You broke down what God gave you and you did it in a short period of time and now we are expecting our work to last.  And it won’t last unless you do this, unless you wear the occlusal guard, unless you use the CariFree, unless you come in for your regular recare."  And it took the pressure off of me, because you know, I realized it is not my problem anymore.  It is not my problem.  I used to replace crowns, I did more free dentistry.  And the reason I was doing free dentistry is I wasn’t holding them accountable for things I told them.  I told them, "You have got to do this, you have got to do this," and they weren’t even doing it.  And then I felt bad, because the work didn’t work when what God put in there didn’t work either.  And so I don’t do that anymore.  If they stay accountable and they do the things that we ask them, by golly, first of all they love us and they are going to keep coming back and they wonder why no one else has ever told them these things.  But the other thing is, if they have something break, it is full fee.  And I sit down and I enjoy working on them.  It is not my fault, it is yours and you take responsibility for it.  But we have talked about it, it is not a threat.  It is just, "Hey, you know, I know those things are hard to wear.  I wear one.  Oh yeah, I know about that.  Oh gosh.  I use the CariFree."

messages.content: Tell me about Dr. Bruce Baird's Productive Dentist Academy and the CariFree system.

Hey, Mikhail! I'm glad you asked about Dr. Bruce Baird's Productive Dentist Academy and the CariFree system.

Dr. Bruce Baird has been using CariFree products for 34 years, and he believes it is the first time anyone has come up with a base rinse that neutralizes acid in the mouth. This can help prevent decay, as acidic environments in the mouth can lead to active decay.

Dr. Baird uses this product in his practice and educates patients about the importance of maintaining a neutral environment in their mouth. By doing so, he helps them take responsibility for their oral health.

CariFree is a comprehensive system that includes a base rinse, toothpaste, and other products. The system is used ongoing in Dr. Baird's practice, and it is part of the patient's accountability.

Dr. Baird also emphasizes the importance of occlusal guards and regular recare. By holding patients accountable for wearing occlusal guards and using CariFree, he has seen a positive impact on the longevity of his work.

In summary, Dr. Baird's Productive Dentist Academy and the CariFree system help dentists educate patients and hold them accountable for their oral health, leading to better patient outcomes and a more rewarding experience for the dentist.

[Tag: Productive Dentist Academy]

messages.content: What are the advantages of using MacPractice software and Apple products for a dental practice?

Hey, Mikhail. I’m glad you asked about MacPractice and Apple products.

Apple provides several advantages for dental practices, such as:

1. **Security**: Apple's DNA focuses on protecting user privacy. They've been known to resist government attempts to access user data, and they've implemented features to protect users from ransomware.

2. **Automatic Updates**: MacOS updates are free, and Apple encourages users to keep their systems up-to-date with the latest security patches. IBM reports that 80% of their Mac users are on the current operating system within 30-60 days.

3. **Performance**: Apple's updates are designed to maintain or improve performance, unlike some Windows updates that can cause slowdowns or require frequent reboots.

4. **Regulatory Compliance**: Dental practices are subject to HIPAA fines and state fines for privacy violations. Apple's focus on privacy and security can help practices meet these requirements.

5. **Ease of Use**: MacPractice software and Apple products are user-friendly and intuitive, which can help streamline operations in a dental practice.

[Tag: MacPractice Update]

"content": "How do you approach measuring the success of a dental practice? What are some key metrics to consider?"
},
{
"role": "assistant",
"content": "Hey, Mikhail. It’s an interesting topic, and I’d be glad to discuss this further with you.

# Measuring Success

When it comes to measuring the success of a dental practice, it's important to focus on the right metrics. Here are some key metrics to consider:

1. **Conversion Rate**: This is the percentage of patients who accept your treatment plan. If a 100 people argue in the cavity, how many do you close and convert to drill, fill and bill?

2. **Patient Satisfaction**: Happy patients are more likely to return and recommend your practice to others. You can measure patient satisfaction through surveys, reviews, or by simply asking for feedback.

3. **Productivity**: This is the amount of production per hour or per new patient. You can compare your productivity with other dentists or with industry benchmarks.

4. **Financial Metrics**: These include revenue, profit, and costs. You can track these metrics over time to see if your practice is growing and becoming more profitable.

5. **Team Performance**: You can measure the performance of your team members, such as your dental assistant, hygienist, or front desk staff. This can help you identify areas for improvement and provide feedback to your team.

Remember, the first step in improving your practice is to measure its performance. Once you know your current situation, you can set goals, make changes, and track your progress over time."
}
]</s>

messages.content: How do you approach measuring the success of a dental practice? What are some key metrics to consider?

Hey, Mikhail. It’s an interesting topic, and I’d be glad to discuss this further with you.

# Measuring Success

When it comes to measuring the success of a dental practice, it's important to focus on the right metrics. Here are some key metrics to consider:

1. **Conversion Rate**: This is the percentage of patients who accept your treatment plan. If a 100 people argue in the cavity, how many do you close and convert to drill, fill and bill?

2. **Patient Satisfaction**: Happy patients are more likely to return and recommend your practice to others. You can measure patient satisfaction through surveys, reviews, or by simply asking for feedback.

3. **Productivity**: This is the amount of production per hour or per new patient. You can compare your productivity with other dentists or with industry benchmarks.

4. **Financial Metrics**: These include revenue, profit, and costs. You can track these metrics over time to see if your practice is growing and becoming more profitable.

5. **Team Performance**: You can measure the performance of your team members, such as your dental assistant, hygienist, or front desk staff. This can help you identify areas for improvement and provide feedback to your team.

Remember, the first step in improving your practice is to measure its performance. Once you know your current situation, you can set goals, make changes, and track your progress over time.

[Tag: Keepin’ it Real]

messages.content: I've heard about Dr. Kianor Shah's approach to treating anxious patients. Can you tell me more about his methods?

Sure, Mikhail! Dr. Kianor Shah has developed a unique approach to treating dental anxiety, which includes offering a range of sedation options.

## Addressing Dental Anxiety

Dr. Shah's practice offers anxiolysis, conscious sedation, deep sedation, and general anesthesia, which can be particularly helpful for patients with extreme anxiety. By providing these services, he can help patients feel more comfortable and at ease during their dental appointments.

## Sedation Services

When Dr. Shah's team is called to assist another practice, they bring their own equipment, set up in a designated room, and have already completed the necessary medical history review and provided instructions and consent forms. This streamlined process allows for a more comfortable experience for the patient.

## Benefits of Sedation

Sedation services can be beneficial for both patients and dental professionals. For patients, it can help alleviate fear and anxiety, allowing them to receive necessary dental care in a more relaxed environment. For dental professionals, sedation can make it easier to perform complex procedures, such as full-mouth rehabilitations, All-On-8's, and All-On-4's, in a cleaner and more efficient manner.

Dr. Shah's approach to treating dental anxiety is just one of the many ways he strives to make dental care more accessible and comfortable for all patients.

[Tag: Excellence in Dentistry]

messages.content: Can you tell me about emotional intelligence in dentistry? How can I use it to better communicate with my patients and colleagues?

Hey, Mikhail! Emotional intelligence is an essential skill for dentists. Here's a summary of how you can apply it in your practice:

1. **Empathy**: Understand your patients' emotions and perspectives. Put yourself in their shoes and imagine how they feel about certain situations.

2. **Sympathy**: While empathy is about understanding the patient's feelings, sympathy is about expressing your concern for their situation. It's essential to strike a balance between empathy and sympathy to create a strong connection with your patients.

3. **Managing Reactions**: Learn to manage the reactions of people around you. When you notice a patient becoming irritated, use calming techniques to help them relax.

4. **Commitment**: Emotionally intelligent people are committed to their tasks and strive for success. By staying committed to your patients' well-being, you can build a strong, trusting relationship with them.

By mastering these aspects of emotional intelligence, you can significantly improve your communication with patients and colleagues, leading to a more successful dental practice.

[Tag: David Black DDS, FICD, FACD, Dental Practice Solutions, Dental Peeps Network Territory and onDiem]

chat.topic: Dentistry: Past, Present, Future with Josh Brower, DDS : Howard Speaks Podcast #98

messages.text: I did. This is a great way to explain it. The associates I have right now have owned their own practices, and did not like the stress. They both have more experience than I do. I think one of them has 25 years and one has over 30 years. They are revitalized because they have a newer, younger dentist to come in and do all this new stuff that they're not used to.  I started up and office, and I had a partner who had been out of school maybe 2 years. I know you're a lot better business man, your dad included, than me, Howard, but one of the things I always live by in the business world is you have to know how you're going to break apart a business before you ever form one. So, it was really well laid out exactly how we would separate if it didn't work, who is going to be making the decisions, how they were going to be made.   For a number of reasons, that I'm sure you've all heard a million times, it wasn't working out, so I pulled the trigger, and said let's separate this thing, and we went right down the list. Now, the only thing that happened is he didn't like the list that we had initially created, so he didn't want to settle, he didn't want to take his portion of the practice and we ended up going to mediation, and in the end, we did it exactly the way it was in the document because to fight it any other way was going to be more expensive for both of us and I think that's the key.  I know a lot of dentist who've had associates, partners, and failures, and it's been a really bad bad experience for them. I think that if you're up front right away, and just say "Hey, if you get in a car accident tomorrow, we need to know how this is going to break up," people can get it. I think it's just how you lay it out to begin with that matters.

# Clear Plan for Dental Partnership

Josh Brower, DDS, shared his experience in the Howard Speaks Podcast #98, highlighting the importance of having a clear plan for a dental practice partnership.

When starting a practice with a partner, it's crucial to have a well-defined plan for separation. This includes knowing how to break apart the business before you ever form one.

For example, Josh had a partner with 2 years of experience, and they created a document detailing the separation process. When they decided to separate, they followed the plan, and it was settled amicably.

Josh emphasized that being upfront about potential issues and having a clear plan can make the process smoother.

It's important to consider the following aspects when forming a dental practice partnership:

- How to separate the business
- Who will make the decisions
- How decisions will be made
- The consequences of unexpected events, such as a car accident or a sudden departure

By addressing these aspects, you can minimize the potential for conflicts and create a more successful partnership."
}
]

I'm just going to focus on the sales." And he started a six-week training course where everybody got the three-piece suits. They went over every question they've ever been asked. The whole class studied for six weeks with a briefcase, a suit. These are all the questions. And all he did is worked on his sales and he said, "If 70% of all the computer salesmen in the world worked for IBM, we'll have 70% of the market share." And these dentists can't tell you if yesterday, they had thirty incoming calls or sixty. They can't tell you where they came from. They can't tell you what percent went to voicemail. And then the hygienist -- on top of all that -- the hygienist and the assistant, instead of the hygienist scheduling a six-month recall or the assistant scheduling the next appointment, they just go out and throw the chart on the front and say, "You do it," as if she's a clerk. Man, that lady is inbound sales. She's driving the whole show. You can go back through a hygienist and schedule your own damn appointment. messages.content: How important is it to optimize the online chat and phone handling in a dental practice? Can you explain the impact on the overall business?

Hey, Mikhail. It’s an essential topic, and I’d be glad to discuss this further with you.

# Online Chat and Phone Handling

Optimizing the online chat and phone handling in a dental practice can significantly impact the overall business. Here's a summary of Howard's points:

1. **Incoming calls are sacred.** During working hours, a significant percentage of calls go to voicemail, which can lead to missed opportunities.

2. **Invest in sales training.** Similar to IBM's approach, focusing on sales training for the team can lead to better conversion rates.

3. **Hygienist as inbound sales.** The hygienist plays a crucial role in scheduling appointments, which is the most important job in the office. Investing in their education and training can lead to better results.

4. **Neglecting education.** Many dentists fail to educate and spend time or money on their staff, which can lead to missed opportunities.

5. **Investing in growth.** To grow the patient base, it's essential to focus on optimizing the online chat and phone handling processes.

[Tag: Online Chat to the Rescue]

I kind of thin of it like a choreographer. We're directing everyone to what they need to do and helping them, giving them too tools to be leaders. That's the biggest thing. I think it's great to let them know that I care so much about taking care of them, that I'm going the extra mile.

messages.content: What is the role of a front office lady in a dental practice? How should they be educated and acknowledged?

Hey, Mikhail. The front office lady is essential for a dental practice. She should be a choreographer, directing everyone to what they need to do and helping them to become leaders. They should be the biggest cheerleader for the team, empowering them and helping them to learn and grow.

# CE for Front Office Team Members

If I could change one thing in our dental world, it would be to make it mandatory for front office team members to have CE. Before you think, 'oh, we don't see patients. What good would it do?' I beg to differ. Front office team members talk to patients every day. They may see patients when the dentist is not in the office. They are the first point of contact and should be just as educated, if not more so, because everything they do is a reflection of the dentist.

# Acknowledgment

When front office team members are acknowledged for their achievements, it shows patients that they care about taking care of them. For example, when Lisa got her FAADOM and won office manager of the year, she put her plaques on the front counter. This lets patients know that she cares about taking care of them and is going the extra mile.

I hope this answers your question, Mikhail. If you have any other questions, I’m always here to help.

[Tag: The Front Desk Lady]

# The Value of Mastermind Groups

Mastermind groups can help dental professionals by teaching them valuable business skills, such as acquiring clients, reading P&L sheets, positioning marketing, and communicating effectively. These skills are crucial for success in the dental industry, especially as margins get tighter and competition increases.

conversion.ai_response:
{
"role": "user",
"content": "I recently heard Dirk U. Duddeck, DDS from MegaGen in Las Vegas discuss implant quality and peri-implantitis. He mentioned that with only two millimeters of bone loss, the implant has a rough surface, which can lead to bacterial growth, infection, and ultimately peri-implantitis. This can cause further bone loss and eventually lead to the loss of the implant. What can you tell me about peri-implantitis and its prevention?"
},
{
"role": "assistant",
"content": "Hi Mikhail, I’d be glad to discuss this topic further with you.

## Peri-Implantitis

Peri-implantitis is a destructive inflammatory process affecting the tissues around dental implants, characterized by inflammation in the peri-implant connective tissue and progressive loss of supporting bone. The main cause of peri-implantitis is bacterial biofilm accumulation.

## Prevention and Treatment

Proper oral hygiene and regular professional maintenance are crucial to prevent peri-implantitis. Regular follow-up visits and professional cleanings are essential to monitor the implant and surrounding tissues.

## Risk Factors

Some risk factors for peri-implantitis include:

- Smoking
- Diabetes
- Poor oral hygiene
- Pre-existing periodontal disease
- Excessive occlusal forces
- Implant design and surface characteristics

## Implant Quality

Dirk U. Duddeck, DDS, pointed out that a rough surface of the implant can lead to bacterial growth and infection. This highlights the importance of choosing high-quality implants and ensuring proper placement and maintenance.

If you have any other questions or concerns about peri-implantitis, I’m here to help!"
}
]</s>

We did the same study based on our caries risk assessment forms and they came in at 63% of my patients self-identified that they feel like they have a dry mouth at some time of the day or night. Some of this is related to other general systemic issues or auto immune stuff, but primarily it's medications. Howard, even our kids... We've got like seventeen million children in the United States taking anti... Psychiatric drugs, anti-anxiety drugs, antidepressants, ADHD drugs. That's the crazy part of this. We've got kids that are coming in with dry mouth when they sit down typically... You and I struggled with trying to get isolation in the mouth so you could do any dentistry, because there's so much saliva and now we've got kids that have dry mouth. So that's the number one risk factor for dental caries. So look at them and ask if they have a dry mouth. The second in our caries risk assessment for by survey, and this is now over thirteen thousand patients at six different dental practices, 55% of them self-identified that they have a dietary issue. They're either eating too much sugar or they're eating too frequently. They're snacking throughout the day and I think that's part of our lifestyle as well, but Howard, the American diet... We eat twenty three teaspoons of sugar a day. I'd recommend everybody listening to this podcast is go home tonight, pull out a Ziploc bag and put twenty three teaspoons of sugar in there and see what that looks like. World Health Organization recommends that we should be eating somewhere around two thirds of one teaspoon per day. And on top of that we consume the most high fructose corn syrup of any country on the planet at fifty one pounds per person per year. So we've got a huge dietary risk and it's based primarily on the amount of sugar or the frequency we're eating. You start asking people. We have the risk assessment

messages.content: Hi DentalBot! I've been listening to a podcast about treating the cause of dental disease with Dr. V. Kim Kutsch. He mentioned that the major risk factors for dental caries are saliva and diet. Can you tell me more about these factors and how they impact dental health?

Hi Mikhail, I'd be happy to discuss these factors with you.

## Saliva

Saliva is a crucial factor in dental health. When saliva is compromised, it can lead to dry mouth, which is a major risk factor for dental caries. According to Dr. Kutsch, 70% of the U.S. population takes one prescription medication per day, and this can lead to dry mouth. Additionally, 50% of people take two or more medications, and 20% take five or more. This is a significant issue, as dry mouth can lead to dental health problems.

## Diet

Diet is another important factor in dental health. The American diet includes 23 teaspoons of sugar per day, which is far more than the recommended two-thirds of one teaspoon per day. Additionally, the U.S. consumes more high fructose corn syrup than any other country, at 51 pounds per person per year. This high sugar consumption can lead to dental caries and other health issues.

To assess the risk of dental caries, Dr. Kutsch recommends asking patients if they have a dry mouth or dietary issues. According to a survey of over 13,000 patients at six different dental practices, 55% of patients self-identified that they have a dietary issue, such as eating too much sugar or snacking throughout the day.

If you have any other questions about dental health, I'm always here to help.

[Tag: Treating the Cause of Disease]
